newsitem.title: UK: Copper reverses after its blistering rally.
newsitem.headline: Copper reverses after its blistering rally.

text.p: Copper prices turned sharply lower on Monday on a belief that a draw on stocks that fuelled a recent rally may be ending.
But traders said that conditions on the London Metal Exchange (LME) are seen remaining volatile, and prices may easily whip higher again.
"It would not take much to get (the market) up..." one said.
Last afternoon kerb business was at $2,187 a tonne, down $55 on Friday and compared with last week's 6-month peak of $2,313.

LME warehouse stocks on Tuesday are expected to register an increase of 2,000-4,000 tonnes. But even though inventories will have risen for two successive reports, if the forecasts prove accurate, the market remains critically short of metal.
Copper's late losses knocked the rest of the metals complex, and nearly all other LME markets turned lower.
Aluminium finished at $1,518 per tonne, down $11 from Friday, but is still looking to consolidate after last week's advances to six-month highs. Stocks are seen lower tomorrow.
Elsewhere in the commodity sector, gold remained weak, fixing in London at $370.50 per ounce before a very modest rebound, and hovering around 20-month lows.
Selling by South African and Australian gold miners as they became increasingly anxious to protect income against falling prices was cited as a major factor eroding the value of gold.
Dealers and analysts also cited a string of clues to the presence of a central bank as a seller in the market including isolated big offerings on the fixings.
"The pressure at the moment is from central banks' selling and speculators who believe that central banks could sell," Fedsure Asset Management analyst Nick Goodwin in Johannesburg said.
U.S. grains prices eased.
Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) soybean futures were lower early on nearly ideal soy crop weather in South America.
Maize was lower on the drop in soybeans and wheat eased on news that Pakistan bought 225,000 tonnes of wheat from Australia and none from the United States.
Early Chicago trading saw January soybeans down 12-3/4 cents at $7.00 a bushel. December wheat was down 2-1/2 cents at $3.93-1/2 per bushel.
Coffee steadied after a dramatic fall last week.
London robusta coffee futures were mostly easier but the January contract managed to end $1 per tonne up on the day at $1,337. Other forward contracts lost up to $17.
Speculative funds continued to sell coffee and the trade and roasters bought on the dips. Values had fallen to 31-month lows on Friday as Januaryslipped through key support at $1,340.
Cocoa eased and sugar was little changed.
World oil prices also traded little changed even as Iraq said it signed export agreements with foreign companies under a delayed oil-for-food agreement with the United Nations.
World benchmark Brent Blend for January delivery was trading above $22.75 a barrel late in London's day.
Some key commodity prices at 1730 GMT on Monday
